docs.lead_paragraph: ''Who's Pulling Your Strings?'' by Dr. Harriet B. Braiker, McGraw-Hill, $21.95. ''The Monster in the Cave,'' by David Mellinger and Dr. Steven Jay Lynn, Berkley, $23.95.
docs.abstract: Book Who's Pulling Your Strings by Dr Harriet B Braiker analyzes individuals who create conflict and drama and gives ideas on ways to disarm them; holds that some victims of manipulation give cues that cause them to be targets of exploitation; David Mellinger and Dr Steven Jay Lynn co-author book The Monster in the Cave, which offers ways for individuals to control panic and anxiety; photos (M)
docs.snippet: ''Who's Pulling Your Strings?'' by Dr. Harriet B. Braiker, McGraw-Hill, $21.95.    ''The Monster in the Cave,'' by David Mellinger and Dr. Steven Jay Lynn, Berkley, $23.95.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study finds that having a stroke puts people at higher risk for developing Alzheimer's disease. Writing in The Archives of Neurology, researchers said the risk was especially high for people with cardiovascular problems or some types of diabetes. The lead author was Dr. Lawrence S. Honig of the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons.
docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence S Honig of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons leads research published in journal Archives of Neurology that shows people who have strokes are at greater risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (S)
docs.snippet: A new study finds that having a stroke puts people at higher risk for developing Alzheimer's disease.    Writing in The Archives of Neurology, researchers said the risk was especially high for people with cardiovascular problems or some types of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sore throats are among the most common reasons that children are taken to doctors, and prescriptions for antibiotics are among the most common results. Now a new study says the drugs do not really help.
docs.abstract: University Medical Center (Utrecht, Netherlands) report, published in BMJ, British medical journal, finds no justification for prescribing antibiotics to children suffering sore throats unless streptococci are present; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Sore throats are among the most common reasons that children are taken to doctors, and prescriptions for antibiotics are among the most common results.    Now a new study says the drugs do not really help.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. John W. Trinkaus is a professor of management as well as a Santa researcher. So when he makes a list, he checks it twice.

headline.main: There Is No Joy in Toyville; Mighty Santa's Striking Out

docs.abstract: Dr John W Trinkaus, Zicklin School of Business professor at Baruch College (NYC), surveys three Santa Claus lines to determine primary emotions of children visiting St Nick; holds that most children are unimpressed with visit to Santa Claus; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. John W. Trinkaus is a professor of management as well as a Santa researcher.    So when he makes a list, he checks it twice.

docs.lead_paragraph: Minuscule particles in air pollution pose a greater risk to the heart than to the lungs, according to a study released yesterday. The particles, called particulate matter, have long been suspected of causing ailments of the heart and lungs. But writing in the journal Circulation, the lead author, Dr. C. Arden Pope III of Brigham Young University, and his colleagues said new research made it clear that the heart was more affected. The study is in the online version of the journal.

headline.main: Tiny Particles Put Heart in Peril

docs.abstract: Dr C Arden Pope III, Brigham Young University researcher, leads study that finds particulate matter, minuscule particles in air pollution, cause more potential damage to heart than to lungs; research, published in journal Circulation, finds that although matter enters body through lungs, very small particles find way to heart and raise risk of ischemic heart disease; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Minuscule particles in air pollution pose a greater risk to the heart than to the lungs, according to a study released yesterday.    The particles, called particulate matter, have long been suspected of causing ailments of the heart and lungs. But...

docs.lead_paragraph: The only advice book I read before my twin sons were born in 1969 was ''Between Parent and Child'' by the psychologist Dr. Haim G. Ginott. It has just been reissued in a reverential revised and updated version by his widow, Dr. Alice Ginott, who is also a psychologist, and Dr. H. Wallace Goddard, a family life specialist. More than five million copies of the original version that ''revolutionized parent-child communication'' have been sold since 1965, and I hope at least as many of the new edition will fall into the eager hands of today's parents and grandparents.

headline.main: Well-Chosen Words Point Children to Right Track

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses parenting book Between Parent and Child,written in 1969 by psychologist Dr Haim G Ginott; text has been revised and updated by his widow Dr Alice Ginott and Dr H Wallace Goddard and recently reissued; holds that appropriate language and communication skills for parents are estential to healthy environment and specific examples of dealing with anger and praise are discussed; contends that effective discipline teaches children that feelings are valid, but frames appropriate behaviors and sets limits; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The only advice book I read before my twin sons were born in 1969 was ''Between Parent and Child'' by the psychologist Dr. Haim G. Ginott. It has just been reissued in a reverential revised and updated version by his widow, Dr. Alice Ginott, who is...

docs.lead_paragraph: The only light in the room is the flicker from the wall-mounted television, thankfully on mute. I watch a car salesman walking through a used car lot mouthing his pitch. Propped by pillows, David lies against the rail of his hospital bed. His right side is paralyzed by a stroke, but he wears a crooked, serene smile. Patrice Repar sings ''Misty'' in a wispy alto, accompanying herself on a portable keyboard.

headline.main: Doctors Promote Healing, With a Zing of the Strings of a Harp

docs.abstract: Dr Ben Daitz, University of New Mexico medical school professor, article discusses experience working with Patrice Repar, former rock musician from Canada who is currently University of New Mexico's Arts in Medicine program director; program seeks to improve healing and quality of life for hospital patients and staff through music and literature; studies that support use of arts in healing process discussed; examples from New Mexico program given (M)
docs.snippet: The only light in the room is the flicker from the wall-mounted television, thankfully on mute. I watch a car salesman walking through a used car lot mouthing his pitch. Propped by pillows, David lies against the rail of his hospital bed.    His...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite excruciating pain and decreased mobility, many people with knees damaged by arthritis put off joint-replacement surgery out of fear and uncertainty. But last week, a federal panel found that replacing a diseased joint with artificial parts quickly relieved pain and improved mobility and quality of life in 90 percent of the patients. The 11-member panel, which the National Institutes of Health convened, also found that the results lasted for years and that women, who could benefit most from total replacement, and minority patients did not have the surgery as often as white men.

headline.main: Federal Panel Gives High Marks to Joint Replacement Surgery

docs.abstract: National Institutes of Health panel, which was established to evaluate joint-replacement surgery, finds procedure highly effective; holds that replacement relieves pain, improves mobility and increases quality of life for 90 percent of patients surveyed; more durable materials and improved surgical techniques also suggest that knee-replacement is effective for younger patients as well as primary group of individuals age 60 to 75; complications of surgery and basic replacement technique discussed; study finds only 1 percent of artificial joints fail each year; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Despite excruciating pain and decreased mobility, many people with knees damaged by arthritis put off joint-replacement surgery out of fear and uncertainty. But last week, a federal panel found that replacing a diseased joint with artificial parts...

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found no evidence that sunscreen, commonly used to reduce the risk of skin cancer, actually increases the risk, researchers said yesterday. Writing in Annals of Internal Medicine, the researchers based their findings on a review of 18 earlier studies that looked at the association between sunscreen use and melanoma. Some studies had suggested that using sunscreen reduced the risk of cancer, but researchers may need decades to determine whether newer, more powerful formulas do more than just prevent sunburn, the study said.
docs.abstract: University of Iowa researchers, led by Dr Leslie K Dennis, publish study in Annals of Internal Medicine that finds no evidence that sunscreen use increases risk of getting skin cancer; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A new study has found no evidence that sunscreen, commonly used to reduce the risk of skin cancer, actually increases the risk, researchers said yesterday.    Writing in Annals of Internal Medicine, the researchers based their findings on a review of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Everyone knows the holiday season can be hazardous to one's health. Just think of the warnings already abundant in the news media, alerting to the perils of gluttony and excess, not to mention overshopping. Even the fitness clubs are gearing up for their post-holiday campaign, in time to capitalize on the ill effects of guilty pleasure. And just when you thought you had all bases covered, up rises the threat of the holiday blues. We are, it seems, to be mentally as well as physically challenged from Christmas to New Year's. Conventional wisdom has it that the season of joy and cheer is really a harbinger of serious depression for some and a general downer and a disappointment for many. Is it really all that bad?

headline.main: A Blue Holiday May Be a Red Herring

docs.abstract: Seasonal Affective disorder, which peaks in fall and winter, is often blamed for blues associated with holiday season; Dr Richard A Friedman holds stressful mental and physical challenges between Christmas and New Year's coupled with unrealistic expectations are for most people more likely reasons for holiday sadness rather than actual disorder; cites that holiday blues are not listed in Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders IV, which is official reference book of American Psychiatric Association; contends that blue holiday feelings are ordinary sadness and disappointment, not mental illness (M)
